articles.title: About this site
articles.description: Some additional details about the website

articles.title: Impacts of Student Habits on Performance
articles.description: In this section, I talk about how various habits like exercising, or phone use impact the perfomance of students.
articles.contents:
Student’s success is not only determined by how rigorous the programs are. They are external factors that may contribute positively or negatively. In this investigation, I try to make connections to these external factors that I believe impact student success.
I will use a random sample of 300 observation since the data set is huge.









Attendance
If students do not attend class, there is a chance that some content will be hard for them to grasp. To look into attendance we have to also look into things that may affect it. An example is Netflix hours.



In this scatter plot, we can see that although the attendance level is varied across the y-axis, as the number of hours spent on Netflix increase, the number of students decrease. Which mean that Netflix can affect attendance.












By observing the width of the bins above in the mosaic graph, with worst and bad mental health we see some low attendance. This emphasizes my assumptions at the beginning. It is worth noting that sometimes students choose not to report their mental health status at the extremities which might be why we have a higher number in the middle.
Mental Health
Mental health is also a big thing in our daily lives. Students can’t do well in school when they are unwell mentally. I believe that exercise rate can impact the mental well being of students.



From the above box plot, we can identify an upward trend. The median of the right most boxplot is higher than those of the two before it. This is a good indication that the better the mental health, the more likely students are to get good scores in exams.
Studying Hours

articles.title: My Website
articles.description: Welcome to the website. I hope you enjoy it!
articles.contents:
Hello there,


My name is Jean Marie Ngabonziza. I am a rising senior, majoring in Computer Science and Engineering. I took the Data Visualization class as part of my Data Science path that I am forging. I aspire to work as a data scientist upon graduation.

articles.title: Infographics
articles.description: In this page I have visualization to tell a story. (REVISE THIS!!)
articles.contents:
ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = age, y = social_media_hours)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity")





# and contains columns 'exam_score' and 'diet_quality'

# Violin Plot
ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = diet_quality, y = exam_score, fill = diet_quality)) +
  geom_violin(trim = FALSE, alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_boxplot(width = 0.1, fill = "white", outlier.shape = NA) +  # optional: add boxplot inside
  labs(
    title = "Exam Scores by Diet Quality",
    x = "Diet Quality",
    y = "Exam Score"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "none")





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = study_hours_per_day, y = exam_score)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", color = "blue") +
  labs(title = "Study Hours vs Exam Score", x = "Study Hours per Day", y = "Exam Score") +
  theme_minimal()





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = attendance_percentage, y = exam_score)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", color = "red") +
  labs(title = "Attendance vs Exam Score", x = "Attendance %", y = "Exam Score") +
  theme_minimal()





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = gender, y = exam_score, fill = gender)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Exam Scores by Gender", x = "Gender", y = "Exam Score") +
  theme_minimal()





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = study_hours_per_day)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 0.5, fill = "skyblue", color = "black") +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Study Hours", x = "Study Hours", y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal()





#ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = netflix_hours, y = exam_score)) +
 # geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +
  #geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
  #labs(title = "Netflix Hours vs Exam Score", x = "Netflix Hours", y = "Exam Score") +
  #theme_minimal()

ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = netflix_hours, y = mental_health_rating, fill = gender)) +
  ggdensity::geom_hdr() +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  labs(
    title = "Netflix Hours vs Mental Health (HDR Visualization)",
    x = "Netflix Hours per Day",
    y = "Mental Health Rating"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = diet_quality, y = sleep_hours, fill = diet_quality)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Sleep Hours by Diet Quality", x = "Diet Quality", y = "Sleep Hours") +
  theme_minimal() + theme(legend.position = "none")





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = internet_quality, y = mental_health_rating, fill = internet_quality)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Mental Health by Internet Quality", x = "Internet Quality", y = "Mental Health Rating") +
  theme_minimal()





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = exercise_frequency, y = exam_score)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.4) +
  geom_smooth(method = "loess", color = "darkorange") +
  labs(title = "Exercise Frequency vs Exam Score", x = "Exercise Frequency", y = "Exam Score") +
  theme_minimal()





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = extracurricular_participation, y = exam_score, fill = extracurricular_participation)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Exam Scores and Extracurricular Participation", x = "Extracurricular?", y = "Exam Score") +
  theme_minimal()





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = parental_education_level, y = exam_score, fill = parental_education_level)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Exam Scores by Parental Education Level", x = "Parental Education", y = "Exam Score") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = study_hours_per_day, y = sleep_hours, fill = study_hours_per_day)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6, color = "purple") +
  labs(title = "Study Hours vs Sleep Hours", x = "Study Hours", y = "Sleep Hours") +
  theme_minimal()





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = sleep_hours, fill = gender)) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.4) +
  labs(title = "Sleep Hour Distributions by Gender", x = "Sleep Hours", y = "Density") +
  theme_minimal()





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = gender, fill = gender)) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(title = "Student Gender Distribution", x = "Gender", y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal()





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = internet_quality, y = exam_score, fill = internet_quality)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Exam Scores by Internet Quality", x = "Internet Quality", y = "Exam Score") +
  theme_minimal()





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = attendance_percentage)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 2, fill = "darkblue", color = "white") +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Attendance", x = "Attendance %", y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal()





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = social_media_hours, y = exam_score)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", color = "steelblue") +
  labs(title = "Device Hours vs Exam Score", x = "Device Use", y = "Exam Score") +
  theme_minimal()





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = gender, y = mental_health_rating, fill = gender)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Mental Health by Gender", x = "Gender", y = "Mental Health Rating") +
  theme_minimal()





p <- ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = study_hours_per_day, y = exam_score)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") +
  labs(title = "Study Hours vs Exam Score", x = "Study Hours", y = "Exam Score")

ggplotly(p)





ggplot(std.habits, aes(x = gender, y = mental_health_rating, fill = gender)) +
  geom_half_violin(side = "l", alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_half_boxplot(side = "r") +
  labs(title = "Mental Health by Gender (Half Violin + Box)") +
  theme_minimal()

articles.title: Previous Plots
articles.description: In this section, I will display graphs that I have created throughout the course. This is to showcase my progress in the material as the semester went on.
articles.contents:
GENERATIVE ART WORK
In this exercise we were required to create art of our choice using R. This was fascinating to me because I did not know R could do something like that. From left to right, the artwork is (1) Rastafari (2) BU Artwork and (3) Swirls.



GGPLOT VISUALIZATIONS
A big part of this course was to analyze data and make meaningful visualizations to tell the stories from the data. In this part I will walk you through an example
of the visualizations we did.



Does the growth of Sepal length affect the Petal length?
In this example, I was working with the iris dataset which gives the mesurements in centimeters of variables of 3 species of iris. Those are sepal length and width, and petal length and width. Particularly, in this visualization, I was investigating if the sepal length has any impact on the petal length. And from the observation, we can see that as the sepal length increases so does the petal length.



However, there is an exception seen in the setosa species which indicates that the sepal growth is not as impactful as in other species. This is what the facets help us to visualize.
INTRO STATS DASHBOARD
To demonstrate our understanding of the introductory statistics concepts, we were asked to make a dashboard for students taking intro stats to help solidify the concepts accompanied by visualizations. My group worked on helping students understand better the concept of sampling distribution. This is a concept that I myself struggled with at first. Understanding that the distribution comes from a statistic computed from many samples of the same size.


MORE VISUALIZATIONS
In this section, I will show 2 distributions from concepts that were new to me or intersting.
1. BOOTSTRAPING DISTRIBUTION
Bootstrapping is a resampling method that allows us to estimate the sampling distribution of a statistic when we don not have enough information or do not want to assume anything about the population distribution.
To me this was fascinating. I did not know that it is possible to infer a statistic with only one good sample representation of the population.



Here, we have a gamma distribution as our pupulation distribution. To build a bootstrap distribution, we need to resample with replacement to get different samples.
We take 10000 samples of the same size to build a bootstrap distribution.



2. GG-HALVES
The gg-halves plot is one that fascinated me throughout the semester. A gg-halves plot is a plot that has two sides each with a different shape. This is done to tell a story in two different perspectives. In the following visualization, I used mtcars dataset and used horsepower, cylinders and transmission.






Here, we can see each violin plot for both automatic and manual being shown above, and it makes for an easy comparision between the two. Fairly quickly, we can see how cars with 8 cylinders vary a lot in horsepower with whether they’re automatic or a manual.
